Our Real Estate Google Ads Framework

We use the CANS Framework.

Each phase serves a role in the funnel. If you're missing one, you're wasting money.

C - Catch

Your search campaign. Targets intent-based buyers and sellers actively searching for homes.

Goal: Show up when people are already looking. Think "homes for sale in [city]" or "top listing agents near me."

A - Amplify

Your retargeting engine. Reminds, reinforces, and re-engages.

Goal: Build trust, reposition the offer, and re-capture clicks from people who didn‚Äôt convert on the first touch.

N - Nurture

Your backend email and SMS sequences. Turn cold leads into hot conversations.

Goal: Follow up automatically and personally. Speed matters here. Leads that aren‚Äôt followed up in 5 minutes might as well not exist.

S - Service

Your actual experience. Not ad-related, but still critical.

Goal: Deliver what you promise in your copy. Great marketing kills a bad client experience faster.

How to Target with Google Ads in Real Estate

Google Ads Keywords

Start with Google Keyword Planner. If you have access to Ahrefs or SEMrush, even better. You're looking for:

  • "Homes for sale in [your city]"
  • "[Your city] real estate agent"
  • "[Your city] top realtor"
  • "[Your city] homes with land/pool/garage/etc"

These are your Catch campaign keywords. They signal buying or selling intent.

For Amplify campaigns, focus on pain points:

  • ‚ÄúStruggling to sell your home?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúFirst-time buyer overwhelmed?‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúTired of getting ghosted by agents?‚Äù

Pair those with retargeting audiences to go deep.

Locational Targeting (Simple)

Target your actual farm. Zip codes. Cities. Radius around listings.
Make sure your ad copy reflects the location this increases click-through rate and Quality Score.

Example:

‚ÄúView All Homes for Sale in Charlotte Under $400K Updated Hourly‚Äù

Locational Targeting (Advanced)

Layer Presence with Interest.

This means targeting users in the location AND interested in the location great for relocation campaigns.

You‚Äôll find this under Location Options ‚Üí Presence or Interest.
Use Interest-based targeting for high-end listings, out-of-state buyers, or second-home investors.

Conversion Tracking Setup

Running ads without tracking is like flying blind. You need visibility into what‚Äôs actually working not just clicks, but conversations, appointments, and closings.

Here‚Äôs how we recommend setting it up:

  1. Use Google Tag Manager
    Set up events for:
    • Form submissions
    • Click-to-call buttons
    • Chat widget opens
    • Schedule links
  2. Link Google Ads with GA4
    This gives you richer attribution and helps train Google‚Äôs machine learning for better optimization.
  3. Assign Values to Conversions
    Even if estimated. This lets Google optimize for actual business outcomes, not just traffic.
  4. Use UTMs in Ad URLs

Here‚Äôs the reality: your brand is your handshake. A well-developed brand supported by consistent messaging does more than just sell properties. It fosters familiarity, trust, and what agents value most: referrals from clients who already trust you.

How Google Ranks Real Estate Websites

The big question: How does Google decide which real estate websites show up first?

It‚Äôs not random. It‚Äôs based on four key factors:

  1. Experience ‚Äì Google prioritizes websites that actually help users. Do you have valuable, useful content? Does your site load fast and work on mobile? If not, you‚Äôre already losing.
  2. Expertise ‚Äì Google wants to rank industry pros. Are you posting market updates, home-buying guides, and neighborhood insights? If not, you‚Äôre just another agent with a website collecting dust.
  3. Authority ‚Äì Are other sites linking to yours? Are you mentioned in local news, real estate blogs, or business directories? The more credible sources that link to you, the higher you rank.
  4. Trustworthiness ‚Äì Does your site look legit? Do you have client reviews, testimonials, and security features in place? Google won‚Äôt rank a site that feels sketchy. Neither will buyers or sellers.

Buyers:

  • Houses for Sale [City]
  • Houses for Sale Near Me
  • Condos for Sale [City]

Sellers:

  • calculate house value
  • determine home value
  • calculate home value
  • home worth estimator

Google Ads & Local Services Ads (LSA) for Realtors

When it comes to generating real estate leads on Google, you have two primary options: Google Ads (PPC) and Local Services Ads (LSAs). ‚Äç

Google Ads vs. Local Services Ads ‚Äì Which One is Better?

The short answer? It depends on your budget, goals, and how hands-on you want to be with lead generation.

‚Äç

Google Ads (PPC ‚Äì Pay-Per-Click)

‚ÄçThese are the traditional text-based ads that appear at the top of Google search results. You bid on keywords like ‚ÄúBest Realtor in [City]‚Äù or ‚ÄúHomes for Sale Near Me‚Äù, and every time someone clicks your ad, you pay a fee.

‚Äç

Local Services Ads (Pay-Per-Lead)

‚ÄçLSAs are different. Instead of paying per click, you only pay when a lead actually contacts you through the ad. These ads appear above Google Ads and include Google‚Äôs ‚ÄúGoogle Screened‚Äù badge, which increases trust with potential clients.

‚Äç

So which is better?

Choose Google Ads (PPC) if:

  • You want more control over who sees your ads
  • You‚Äôre willing to optimize landing pages and follow up aggressively
  • You have a larger budget to test different campaigns

Choose Local Services Ads (LSAs) if:

  • You want low-risk, high-intent leads
  • You don‚Äôt want to worry about click-through rates and wasted spend
  • You prefer a pay-per-lead model vs. per click

The best approach? Use both. LSAs provide guaranteed leads, while Google Ads let you scale aggressively.

‚Äç

You apply & get Google Screened - This requires submitting your license, background check, and proof of business.

You set your budget & locations - Unlike PPC, you‚Äôre not bidding on keywords. Instead, you set a weekly budget for leads in a specific area.

Leads come in & you only pay for real inquiries - If a lead contacts you but isn‚Äôt serious, you can dispute the charge with Google.

Your ranking is based on your profile & reviews - LSAs prioritize agents with more 5-star Google reviews and a high response rate.

Feature Google Ads (PPC) Local Services Ads (LSA)
Payment Model Pay-Per-Click (PPC) Pay-Per-Lead (PPL)
Ad Placement Below LSAs, above organic results Top of Google search
Lead Intent Medium ‚Äì Some window shoppers High ‚Äì Ready-to-talk leads
Optimization Needed High ‚Äì Keywords, landing pages, bid adjustments Low ‚Äì Focus on reviews & responsiveness
Risk Level Higher ‚Äì You pay whether leads convert or not Lower ‚Äì Only pay when contacted

For most agents, a combination of both is the best approach‚ÄîLSAs for direct leads and Google Ads for brand awareness and volume.

‚Äç

FAQ on Google for Realtors

1. How long does it take to see results from Google My Business and SEO?

SEO is a long-term strategy. You can start seeing traction from Google My Business in a few weeks if you actively collect reviews and post updates. SEO can take 3‚Äì6 months to gain traction, but once ranked, it generates leads consistently without ad spend.

‚Äç

2. Is Google My Business better than Zillow for generating leads?

Yes. GMB leads are inbound and organic, meaning they‚Äôre reaching out to you instead of you paying for cold leads like Zillow. With Zillow, you rent leads; with Google, you own them.

‚Äç

3. Do I need to run Google Ads, or can I rely on organic traffic?

Both work, but it depends on your goals. If you need immediate leads, Google Ads & Local Services Ads (LSA) are the fastest way to get in front of motivated buyers and sellers. SEO takes time, but it‚Äôs a long-term investment that reduces your dependency on paid ads.

‚Äç

4. What‚Äôs the best way to rank higher in Google search results?

  • Optimize your Google My Business profile with complete info, reviews, and regular updates.
  • Create neighborhood pages & blog content on your website targeting local keywords.
  • Use YouTube videos to rank for local searches.
  • Ensure your site is mobile-friendly and fast (Google prioritizes user experience).

‚Äç

5. How much should I budget for Google Ads or LSA?

It depends on your market, but a good starting point is $500‚Äì$1,500 per month for Google Ads and $50 per lead for LSA. However, LSA is pay-per-lead, so your cost is directly tied to how many inquiries you receive.

‚Äç

6. How can I track my success on Google?

Use Google My Business Insights to track calls, website visits, and direction requests.
Use Google Analytics & Google Search Console to see where traffic is coming from and which keywords drive results.

‚Äç

7. What‚Äôs the biggest mistake realtors make with Google?

They set it and forget it. Google rewards consistency, so agents who regularly update their GMB profile, create local content, and tweak their ads get more visibility and better leads over time.
